{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3703474,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T01:38:10.760Z","cooked":"

What are y‚Äôall‚Äôs favorite sensors for beam-break/presence that work in direct sun?

I love the ~$5 Amazon IR sensors, but they fail with moderate amounts of interference.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B0CQZX3N52/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?smid=ATCVC199CHVK0&psc=1

We switched to CANRange this year with the hope that the distance sensing package would not be affected by generic sunlight interference, but found out this summer that actually we still can‚Äôt run automation that depends on the ‚Äúpresence‚Äù thresholding outdoors. (They do tend to operate ok under a canopy at least.)

Has anyone found a single-sided beam break or presence sensor that‚Äôll handle full sunlight interference well?
Have you found a two sided (emitter/receiver) solution that works for full sun?

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T01:41:11.721Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":11,"reads":314,"readers_count":313,"score":147.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.amazon.com/gp/aw/d/B0CQZX3N52/ref=ox_sc_act_title_1?smid=ATCVC199CHVK0&psc=1","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"NOYITO E3F-DS30P1 Proximity Switch Photoelectric Sensor Switch 30cm Adjustable Detection Distance Diffuse Reflection Infrared Switch DC 6-36V 3-Wire PNP NO: Amazon.com: Industrial & Scientific","clicks":23}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3703490,"name":"Pedro Braga","username":"predobrega","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/predobrega/{size}/211207_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T02:33:57.276Z","cooked":"

I wonder if ultrasonic range sensors would be acceptable for your application, since they won‚Äôt affected by sunlight.

If you really need to use optical sensors, I would try using laser based sensors (probably beam break instead of LIDAR), with a shroud around the emmiter/receiver.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T02:39:15.395Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":283,"readers_count":282,"score":61.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"Pedro Braga","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703518,"name":"Zachary","username":"Zatack7","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zatack7/{size}/175437_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T02:42:33.262Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôm not sure how good the pricey banner ones that are also in first choice are about the sun, but they might be an option. Worth looking into.
You could also cause a massive volcanic eruption, triggering an ash cloud that blocks out the sun.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T02:42:33.262Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":272,"readers_count":271,"score":184.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"Zachary","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53819,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"ban the rev 40a breaker"},"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/3","custom_user_title":"ban the rev 40a breaker","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703559,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T03:06:29.501Z","cooked":"

We‚Äôve had really good experiences with these AutomationDirect beam breaks. They‚Äôre a bit pricey, but fairly immune to outside light interference (we‚Äôve never had any issues with them, even on outdoor demos). I think the way the receivers lens is designed makes it more directional than other sensors, thus making it more tolerant to light bouncing from other sources‚Ä¶ or something like that. The only downside is you have to do a little creative wiring to use them since they require 12v power delivery.

I find that ‚ÄúVisible Red‚Äù line break sensors like these tend to be far more reliable than IR-based sensors or photoreflective sensors. We‚Äôve used the CANRange quite a bit this year as well and have been happy with it, though our implementation is not quite as ambient-light sensitive (it‚Äôs somewhat enclosed, and very short-range).

Any optical sensor is going to have a limit to how much ambient light it can handle before the sensor is ‚Äúdazzled‚Äù (like if you‚Äôve ever been blinded walking out from a dark room into bright sunlight). You can mitigate this with ‚Äúshielding‚Äù (blocking out at least some ambient light), using a physical contact sensor instead (like a limit switch), or possibly even ultrasonic sensors (though those are also prone to different types of interference).

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T03:11:29.679Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":130.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.automationdirect.com/adc/shopping/catalog/sensors_-z-_encoders/photoelectric_sensors/through-beam/qmrhd-0n-0a","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":33}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703571,"name":"s-neff","username":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T03:15:31.500Z","cooked":"

I see your point about ultrasonic physics working better, and I‚Äôve also just never seen the Maxbotics as a Production quality device. Probably because most of the ones I‚Äôve used are in their fifth or tenth or fiftieth ‚Äúmy first sensor feedback‚Äù workshop iteration and getting a bit worse for the wear from repeated use by new engineers in training‚Ä¶

cbale2000:

require 12v power delivery.

Like nice regulated 12v?
I wouldn‚Äôt mind sticking a tiny regulator next to it, we run battery power everywhere already.

Tell me more about how you‚Äôre avoiding dazzle on your CANRange? Ours is high on the robot mounted to clear polycarbonate and looking at more clear polycarbonate, so there is definitely currently many ways for lots of ambient light to arrive at it‚Ä¶

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T03:17:57.582Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":225,"readers_count":224,"score":110.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"s-neff","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28019,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703616,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T03:33:05.864Z","cooked":"

It‚Äôs 10v-30v tolerant, so it‚Äôs not required, but a regulator also never hurts.
Technically since it‚Äôs an NPN ‚Äúphotoswitch‚Äù I also read somewhere that you need to add a certain resistor to the circuit to make it so the RoboRIO can detect it properly over DIO, but we always just wired them to the analog inputs and set the threshold voltage manually.

For dazzle prevention, basically the thing to remember is that if a CANRange isn‚Äôt seeing the bounce-back from the laser, the range reading is essentially ‚Äúinfinity‚Äù, in the use-case of a presence (game piece, usually) detector, we really only care that the sensor can see the reflection of the laser when the object it‚Äôs trying to detect is there. To that end, reducing the distance between the object and the sensor as much as possible (within the minimum limits of the sensor) helps a lot. After that, you just have to consider ways to reduce the light that‚Äôs getting in between the thing you‚Äôre trying to detect and the sensor.

If you were dealing with a polycarbonate intake, one method might be to use smoked polycarbonate or even something as simple as a sharpie or some non-clear tape to block light from entering. You don‚Äôt need to create a perfect black-out seal or anything, just reduce the total luminance so the laser can shine through it.

One other thing we did on our polycarbonate intake was design it with a hole for the sensor to see though (the CANRange should have an unobstructed view, don‚Äôt shine it through poly if possible), and then took a sharpie to the inside edges of the hole (with the sensor removed) to blacken it. Clear plastics can act a bit like a fiber optic cable and transmit light in every direction through them, creating a kind of glow that can affect sensors (acrylic does this best, but poly does too, to a degree).

Lastly, make sure your CANRange is set to ‚ÄúShort Range‚Äù detection mode for best results.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T03:40:19.960Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":199,"readers_count":198,"score":114.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/CrossTheRoadElec/Device-CADs/raw/refs/heads/master/CANRANGE_CAD/CANrange%2520CAD.zip","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":3}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28019,"username":"s-neff","name":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703875,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T13:02:24.515Z","cooked":"

Our solution is to recess the sensor or 3d print a small circular ‚Äòcowl‚Äô (out of mat black filament) to place directly around the receive side of the sensor. We also engineer the solutions to never look ‚Äúup‚Äù, always down. This seems to have solved our issues, even with the more sensitive sensors.

Another item to consider is to make sure that the surfaces on the opposite side from he sensor are not reflective. We often throw some black gaffers tape to prevent indirect reflections of bright lights.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T13:02:24.515Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":140,"readers_count":139,"score":118.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/7","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703876,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T13:12:35.426Z","cooked":"

We used Maxbotixs extensively, wayyyyyy back in 2008-2011. What we found was that for ‚Äòreal time‚Äô sensing, it was simply not accurate or fast enough. To obtain an accurate measurement relied on significant filtering because of fluctuations in the returned signal. The filtering added into the 20hz response rate was simply to slow for what we wanted (monitoring distance from the wall real time as we drove toward it). I‚Äôm not sure what the current state of the sensor library is, but the return signal is also non-linear, and you needed to use a formula or create a regression to change the returned signal into a human readable distance. Between adjusting the regression formula, the signal filtering, and the read time, it wasn‚Äôt what we wanted.

All those combined together led us away from the Maxbotics and toward faster sensors - the Garmin style laser sensor worked well for us for real-time fast distance monitoring.

Now, we just use one of the many can-enabled laser rangefinders on the market.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T13:12:35.426Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":138,"readers_count":137,"score":32.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":28019,"username":"s-neff","name":"s-neff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/s-neff/{size}/9062_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/8","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703880,"name":"Chris LaSalle","username":"robo5142","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T13:25:29.362Z","cooked":"

Try this

Redux Robotics

Phosphorus Canandcolor

Price: USD 45

This device can sense position or color. We used it last season to sense coral in our end effector.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":12,"updated_at":"2025-08-06T13:25:29.362Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":124,"readers_count":123,"score":24.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":505006,"topic_slug":"sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors","display_username":"Chris LaSalle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://shop.reduxrobotics.com/phosphorus-canandcolor/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Phosphorus Canandcolor","clicks":10}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":7841,"username":"Tom_Line","name":"Tom Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":47189,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/sunproof-beam-break-presence-sensors/505006/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3703931,"name":"Bryce Roethel","username":"bryceroethel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bryceroethel/{size}/265913_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-06T15:30:09.536Z","cooked":"
Zatack7:

I‚Äôm not sure how good the pricey banner ones that are also in first choice are about the sun, but they might be an option. Worth looking into.

340 has been using these sensors from Banner for years and has had great success with them. It utilizes a polarized reflective target which makes the sensor more resilient to light pollution. We‚Äôve ran them outside for demos and haven‚Äôt experienced any problems.

IMG_10731052√ó894 161 KB

A different sensor from Banner is typically offered in the KoP with the required cable, which we usually request. The sensor does require a regulated input voltage, we typically power it through the VRM.

We used the lasercan this year, and in testing saw with my phones light directly on the sensor or totally blocking light around it, it had no trouble detecting notes.
